item.title: Coding
item.description: On this page, you will find resources associated with each session in the coding workshop series. A few days before each session, please check this page to make sure you’ve downloaded any necessary files in advance (if needed). After each session, the page will be updated with links any additional materials/answer keys/etc. that were referenced during the workshop. Week 1: Setting up your R environment Before the workshop: download these files: data file, RMarkdown file, R Project file After the workshop: RMarkdown file (with answers) Note: If you have trouble knitting your Rmd file, find the code chunk where you load in a set of packages (using the library() function), and remove the text eval = False.

item.title: Coding (basic) - 2021
item.description: See below for resources associated with the basic-track coding workshops from SIPPS 2021. For other workshops from 2021, follow this link. Week 1: Setting up your R environment View Recording Before the workshop: download these files: data file, RMarkdown file, R Project file After the workshop: RMarkdown key Week 2: Programming fundamentals View Recording Before the workshop: please create a folder named 02_intro-programming on your computer download these files within that folder: data file (shakes.

item.title: Coding (advanced) - 2021
item.description: See below for resources associated with the advanced-track coding workshops from SIPPS 2021. For other workshops from 2021, follow this link. Week 1: Refresher of regression and moderation (frequentist) View Recording Before the workshop: make sure you have both R and RStudio downloaded on your machine; if you don’t, check out this page for guidance Workshop materials: R packages used today: tidyverse (contains ggplot2, dplyr, and others); car intro to regression slides RMarkdown lesson file (with notes) RMarkdown challenge file / answer key

item.title: About the SIPPS Program
item.description: The SIPPS team comprises a group of graduate students, post-docs, undergraduates, and faculty advisors who are committed to diversity and inclusion, in its broadest sense. We are scientists whose day-to-day research seeks to understand how people think, behave, and relate to one other and how differences in our experiences, both positive and adverse, affect our brain, relationships, and behavior. Our work encompasses and embraces the ideas of diversity and support.

item.title: Apply
item.description: Applications for SIPPS 2022 are now closed. Have any questions about next year’s program? Our plans for SIPPS 2023 might not be finalized until next year, but please feel free to reach out to sippscupsych@gmail.com with any questions.

item.description: The SIPPS team comprises a group of graduate students, post-docs, undergraduates, and faculty advisors who are committed to diversity and inclusion, in its broadest sense. We are scientists whose day-to-day research seeks to understand how people think, behave, and relate to one other and how differences in our experiences, both positive and adverse, affect our brain, relationships, and behavior. Our work encompasses and embraces the ideas of diversity and support.

item.title: Instructor Materials
item.description: Quick links for graduate students, postdocs, and staff in charge of putting on the SIPPS program. Feel free to disregard if you are a participant in this program. Please contact Manasi if you are unable to access any of the links below. instructor schedule SIPPS Drive folder guidelines for instructors guidelines for independent research projects mentor/mentee contract post-workshop exit survey

item.title: Meet the SIPPS Team
item.description: SIPPS is a program developed & run primarily by graduate students, postdocs, and staff in Columbia’s Psychology Department. Core Team Ana DiGiovanni is a PhD student in the Couples Lab. She studies social support processes and interpersonal emotion regulation strategies (i.e., co-rumination) that occur in close relationships, especially during times of stress. email Claudia Espinoza-Heredia is a PhD student working with Dima Amso in the DCN Lab, interested in the role of environmental factors and experience on early brain maturation.

item.title: Resources
item.description: On this page you will find an assortment of miscellaneous resources that you may find useful as a student interested in psychological research. Please note that all materials developed for specific workshop sessions will instead be found on the workshops page. Don’t hesitate to reach out to your mentor(s) and/or your instructors with specific questions about these resources. Summer Research Funding See this spreadsheet for a list of summer funding opportunities.

item.title: Schedule
item.description:
SIPPS 2022 workshops will take place in-person on Columbia University’s Morningside campus. The exact location will be shared via email with those admitted to the SIPPS program.
SIPPS hosts three parallel workshop series, each with one session per week. See below for a detailed overview of all workshop topics and dates, and see the workshops page for materials associated with each session. If you miss a workshop and need to access the recording, please reach out to the SIPPS team at please sippscupsych@gmail.

item.title: SIPPS Mini-Conference
item.description:
Check out the presentations made by previous SIPPS participants during our end-of-summer conference! SIPPS 2021 Poster presentations The relationship between trait anxiety and hypnotic suggestibility Charlotte Cassidy Mentor: Ben Silver
Co-rumination, closeness, and the use of we-language Margot Deregnaucourt Mentor: Ana DiGiovanni
Are age-related changes in hippocampal granularity in older adults associated with verbal episodic memory? Elena Gadekar Mentor: John Thorp
